articles.headline: The Delicate Dance of a Progressive C.E.O. in the Trump Era
articles.snippet: J. Clifford Hudson is a Democrat who values diversity at his company, Sonic Drive-In. But he knows that some of his franchise owners and their customers may not share his views.
articles.abstract: J. Clifford Hudson is a Democrat who values diversity at his company, Sonic Drive-In. But he knows that some of his franchise owners and their customers may not share his views.
articles.lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — One of the most formative experiences of J. Clifford Hudson’s life happened about 20 minutes away from the glass-walled office he now occupies as the chief executive of Sonic Drive-In, the burger-and-milkshake chain.

articles.headline: Kazakhstan Cheers New Alphabet, Except for All Those Apostrophes
articles.snippet: A switch from the Cyrillic to Roman script is wildly popular in Kazakhstan. But in a country where almost nobody challenges the president, his policy on apostrophes is being assailed from all sides.
articles.abstract: A switch from the Cyrillic to Roman script is wildly popular in Kazakhstan. But in a country where almost nobody challenges the president, his policy on apostrophes is being assailed from all sides.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALMATY, Kazakhstan — In his 26 years as Kazakhstan’s first and only president, Nursultan A. Nazarbayev has managed to keep a resurgent Russia at bay and navigate the treacherous geopolitical waters around Moscow, Beijing and Washington, keeping on good terms with all three capitals.

articles.headline: Alexa, We’re Still Trying to Figure Out What to Do With You
articles.snippet: Many people use digital assistants for the basics, like the weather forecast or music. It’s a long way from the digital home envisioned by their makers.
articles.abstract: Many people use digital assistants for the basics, like the weather forecast or music. It’s a long way from the digital home envisioned by their makers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — These days, you can find virtual assistants like Amazon’s Alexa or Google’s Assistant in all sorts of things, from smart speakers and smartphones to washing machines and bathroom mirrors.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: One Year After Women’s March, More Activism but Less Unity
articles.snippet: Women’s March Inc., which organized the event in Washington, has encouraged more protests. But a new group is focused on winning elections, especially in red states.
articles.abstract: Women’s March Inc., which organized the event in Washington, has encouraged more protests. But a new group is focused on winning elections, especially in red states.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amber Selman-Lynn wanted to help plan a women’s march in Mobile, Ala., this month to mark the first anniversary of last year’s huge protests across the country. The day had been significant for her.

articles.headline: As Shutdown Talk Rises, Trump’s Immigration Words Pose Risks for Both Parties
articles.snippet: The fight over President Trump’s vulgar comment is exposing divisions in both parties, raising the risk of a government shutdown with unknown political consequences.
articles.abstract: The fight over President Trump’s vulgar comment is exposing divisions in both parties, raising the risk of a government shutdown with unknown political consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s incendiary words about immigration have dampened the prospects that a broad spending and immigration deal can be reached by the end of the week, raising the possibility of a government shutdown with unknown political consequences for lawmakers in both parties.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin, Michael D. Shear and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Workplace Raids Signal Shifting Tactics in Immigration Fight
articles.snippet: The Trump administration says its actions show the price of employing workers illegally, a message being felt keenly among the workers themselves.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration says its actions show the price of employing workers illegally, a message being felt keenly among the workers themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Trump administration is taking its campaign against illegal immigration to the workplace.

articles.headline: Democrats Add Momentum to G.O.P. Push to Loosen Banking Rules
articles.snippet: The Senate is poised to approve significant changes to the post-crisis financial law. Some moderate Democrats are supporting the effort, even as their progressive colleagues warn that it’s too risky.
articles.abstract: The Senate is poised to approve significant changes to the post-crisis financial law. Some moderate Democrats are supporting the effort, even as their progressive colleagues warn that it’s too risky.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The most significant attempt to loosen rules imposed in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis is underway in Congress as the Senate looks to pass legislation within the next month that would roll back restrictions on swaths of the finance industry.

articles.headline: Chinese Carmaker May Use Fiat Chrysler for Foothold in United States
articles.snippet: GAC Motor said it planned to bring an S.U.V. to the United States in 2019. It may use Fiat Chrysler dealerships hungry for new models.
articles.abstract: GAC Motor said it planned to bring an S.U.V. to the United States in 2019. It may use Fiat Chrysler dealerships hungry for new models.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — For years, as China emerged as the world’s largest producer of automobiles, American car companies have wondered when a Chinese manufacturer would try to enter the United States market.

articles.headline: BlackRock’s Message: Contribute to Society, or Risk Losing Our Support
articles.snippet: Laurence Fink, the chief executive of BlackRock, the $6 trillion investment firm, plans to tell C.E.O.s in a letter that businesses must serve a social purpose.
articles.abstract: Laurence Fink, the chief executive of BlackRock, the $6 trillion investment firm, plans to tell C.E.O.s in a letter that businesses must serve a social purpose.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, the chief executives of the world’s largest public companies will be receiving a letter from one of the most influential investors in the world. And what it says is likely to cause a firestorm in the corner offices of companies everywhere and a debate over social responsibility that stretches from Wall Street to Washington.

articles.headline: Oil Price Briefly Reaches $70 as Buoyant Global Economy Bolsters Demand
articles.snippet: Tensions in Iran, record-breaking cold weather in the United States and a year of production cuts have contributed to higher prices, and they could go higher still.
articles.abstract: Tensions in Iran, record-breaking cold weather in the United States and a year of production cuts have contributed to higher prices, and they could go higher still.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tensions in Iran. Cold weather in the United States. A year of production cuts. With 2018 still young, there has been no shortage of reasons oil prices are pushing higher.

articles.headline: At G.E., $6.2 Billion Charge for Finance Unit Hurts C.E.O.’s Turnaround Push
articles.snippet: The charge, which was primarily tied to long-term care insurance reinsured as part of the GE Capital unit’s portfolio, was a blow to John Flannery’s turnaround campaign.
articles.abstract: The charge, which was primarily tied to long-term care insurance reinsured as part of the GE Capital unit’s portfolio, was a blow to John Flannery’s turnaround campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Electric delivered another disappointing surprise to investors on Tuesday, taking a $6.2 billion charge to pay for lingering problems in its finance unit.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr and Chad Bray
